@aShevc 
Thanks for the reply. 

But I am wondering how to guarantee fault tolerance of Scheduler & TMaster? Let's say, what happen when Scheduler & TMaster fail? Anyone to restart it?

Also, does it also require there is no firewall between the host doing submission and the hosts running rest containers?
@maosongfu done. I'm echoing back `cluster_role_env`, from which we can infer parts.
Looks good, thanks!

Hi @alanngai, based on the branch of  `alan/pylint-rcfile` from your heron fork. I found the following problems:
1. In BUILD file: `"help.py",` should be `"cli_helper.py"` on line 12
2. In `main.py`: `import heron.cli.src.python.help as cli_help` should be `import heron.cli.src.python.cli_helper as cli_helper` on line 26, and change the following occurrence of `cli_help` to `cli_helper`.
3. In `main.py`: `cli_help.create_parser(subparsers)` only provides one argument while the method in `cli_helper.py` requires 3 parameters: `def create_parser(subparsers, action, help):`. I think we should either remove this line, or find the proper arguments for it. 
4. In `submit.py`: `javaDefines=cl_args['topology_main_jvm_property'])` on line 175 should be `java_defines=cl_args['topology_main_jvm_property'])`
5. In `submit.py`: `javaDefines=[]` on line 106 should be `java_defines=[]`

After that, I can launch launch a topology successfully. But there might be other problems.

I tried with other heron operations and  found following problems: 

`kill` is not invoked correctly.

``` bash
[tw-mbp-nlu heron (alan/pylint-rcfile)]$ heron kill local nlu-ex
INFO: heron_class 10
INFO: heron_class 20
[2016-06-09 14:23:44 -0700] com.twitter.heron.spi.utils.TMasterUtils SEVERE:  Topology is already activateed  
INFO: Successfully activate topology 'nlu-ex'
INFO: Elapsed time: 2.971s.
```

`deactivate` is not invoked correctly.

``` bash
[tw-mbp-nlu heron (alan/pylint-rcfile)]$ heron deactivate local nlu-ex
INFO: heron_class 10
INFO: heron_class 20
[2016-06-09 14:27:26 -0700] com.twitter.heron.spi.utils.TMasterUtils SEVERE:  Topology is already activateed  
INFO: Successfully activate topology 'nlu-ex'
INFO: Elapsed time: 2.935s.
```

They are all bind to `activate` instead. Other operations `restart`, `version` and `activate` are behaving correctly. The problem relates to the changes you made in `kill.py` and `deactivate.py` that reusing the `cli_helper`'s run method.

Could you fix those problems and let me know?
It would be nice to also have this note visible in the Quick Start guide: http://twitter.github.io/heron/docs/getting-started/
üëç

I am using HDFS uploader for the aurora cluster. I am getting the following error upon submitting the topology:

```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Invalid path string "/hdfs:///heron/topologies/foo" caused by empty node name specified @7
```

These are my config files:

scheduler.yaml

```
# scheduler class for distributing the topology for execution
heron.class.scheduler: com.twitter.heron.scheduler.aurora.AuroraScheduler

# launcher class for submitting and launching the topology
heron.class.launcher: com.twitter.heron.scheduler.aurora.AuroraLauncher

# location of the core package
heron.package.core.uri: hdfs:///tmp/.heron/dist/heron-core.tar.gz

# location of java - pick it up from shell environment
heron.directory.sandbox.java.home: /usr/lib/jvm/java-8-oracle

# Invoke the IScheduler as a library directly
heron.scheduler.is.service: False
```

statemgr.yaml

```
# local state manager class for managing state in a persistent fashion
heron.class.state.manager: com.twitter.heron.statemgr.zookeeper.curator.CuratorStateManager

# local state manager connection string
heron.statemgr.connection.string:  "masternode:2181"

# path of the root address to store the state in a local file system
heron.statemgr.root.path: "hdfs:///heron"

# create the zookeeper nodes, if they do not exist
heron.statemgr.zookeeper.is.initialize.tree: True

# timeout in ms to wait before considering zookeeper session is dead
heron.statemgr.zookeeper.session.timeout.ms: 30000

# timeout in ms to wait before considering zookeeper connection is dead
heron.statemgr.zookeeper.connection.timeout.ms: 30000

# timeout in ms to wait before considering zookeeper connection is dead
heron.statemgr.zookeeper.retry.count: 10

# duration of time to wait until the next retry
heron.statemgr.zookeeper.retry.interval.ms: 10000
```

uploader.yaml

```
# uploader class for transferring the topology jar/tar files to storage
heron.class.uploader: com.twitter.heron.uploader.hdfs.HdfsUploader

# Directory of config files for hadoop client to read from
heron.uploader.hdfs.config.directory: /usr/local/hadoop/etc/hadoop

# name of the directory to upload topologies for HDFS uploader
heron.uploader.hdfs.topologies.directory.uri: hdfs:///heron/topologies/${CLUSTER}
```

client.yaml

```
# location of the core package
heron.package.core.uri:                      "hdfs:///tmp/.heron/dist/heron-core.tar.gz"

# Whether role/env is required to submit a topology. Default value is False.
heron.config.is.role.required:               False
heron.config.is.env.required:               False
```

Is there anything wrong in the config files?

It seems after:
1. specify the -xms explicitly
2. +XX:+AlwaysPreTouch always takes the full ram at the start
will make two integration tests topology (which specify most instances, one specifies 6 while another specifies 7; and 1GB ram by default per instance) exceeds the ram limitation of travis-ci building env, which is 7.5GB. (https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/ci-environment/#Virtualization-environments)
it'ok when switch to centos 7 (glibc 2.17) @maosongfu

With Ubuntu 14.04.4 server, I faced the same issue of the missing file 
`/home/USER/.herondata/repository/state/local/pplans/ExclamationTopology`
and this also resulted in an empty diagram or image for Logical Topology in the heron-ui web view as well as empty metrics and containers and such.

These minimal dependencies solved it for me:
`$ sudo apt-get install unzip libunwind-setjmp0`
and the heron-ui topology view now contains these diagrams (circled):
![heron-fixed](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1231235/16008740/a37e643c-3179-11e6-8398-b4e2d81bf2cd.png)

But still no log files
`heron-executor.stderr` or `heron-executor.stdout`
in
`.herondata/topologies/local/USER/ExclamationTopology/log-files/`
@maosongfu Thanks! Its running now.

@lilalinda 
`heron-executor.stderr` or `heron-executor.stdout` is in
`.herondata/topologies/local/USER/ExclamationTopology/`
, rather than in 
`.herondata/topologies/local/USER/ExclamationTopology/log-files/`

@Udit93 
https://github.com/twitter/heron/pull/902/files

```
It is also possible that the host has an issue with resolving localhost. To check, run the following command in a shell.

$ python -c "import socket; print socket.gethostbyname(socket.gethostname())"
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
socket.gaierror: [Errno 8] nodename nor servname provided, or not known
If the output looks like a normal IP address, such as 127.0.0.1, you don't have this issue. If the output is similar to the above, you need to modify the /etc/hosts file to correctly resolve localhost, as shown below.

Run the following command, whose output is your computer's hostname.

$ python -c "import socket; print socket.gethostname()"
Open the /etc/hosts file as superuser and find a line containing

127.0.0.1   localhost
Append your hostname after the word "localhost" on the line. For example, if your hostname was tw-heron, then the line should look like the following:

127.0.0.1   localhost   tw-heron
Save the file. The change should usually be reflected immediately, although rebooting might be necessary depending on your platform.
```

It's meant to address `pip` issues that may arise when running `make setup` and to delete the `linkchecker-out.csv` file once the linkchecking process is finished (that file is superfluous once the linkchecker script is finished and should be removed so that it doesn't accidentally get committed to Git).

Thanks @castomer!

This is a bazel issue. All timestamps get reset upon packaging. Need to investigate more to see if we can change this.
https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/issues/1299
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/bazel-discuss/cprd0UhRMAs
https://github.com/bazelbuild/bazel/search?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=198001010000
These are warnings that can be ignored. Untarring with `--warning=no-timestamp` should suppress the warning. See https://www.gnu.org/software/tar/manual/html_node/warnings.html
@billonahill - awesome. Can we fix the scripts where we untar? They are the installer scripts.
@maosongfu Yes, you are right that the log files are indeed a level higher than expected.  Now I declare success with the local getting-started example. Thanks!

I modified get_all_heron_paths.sh file, add a parameter --config = centos, now works correctly.

![default](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19700922/16071301/2feb9f68-330d-11e6-83e2-da2cd7e2d49d.jpg)

When we build manually we provide the config=<platform> but in IDEA you need to query the platform and accordingly pass the platform. 

for ubuntu, it is --config=ubuntu
for mac, it is --config=darwin
for centos, it is --config=centos

It will be great if you could provide a patch to fix this.

After statically linking - the libraries used were as follows:

```
ubuntu@ip-172-31-10-44:~/heron/bazel-out/local_linux-fastbuild/bin/heron/tmaster/src/cpp$ ldd heron-tmaster
    linux-vdso.so.1 =>  (0x00007ffd8b9ad000)
    libstdc++.so.6 => /usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libstdc++.so.6 (0x00007f3d95ba3000)
    libm.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libm.so.6 (0x00007f3d9589d000)
    libpthread.so.0 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007f3d9567f000)
    librt.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/librt.so.1 (0x00007f3d95477000)
    libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f3d95261000)
    libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f3d94e9c000)
    /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f3d95ea7000)
```

This eliminates the dynamic dependencies of libunwind and liblzma linking

That's a bug that we don't pass `--config=[os]` to bazel on that line. I suggest we fix by defaulting to `--config=darwin` (the most common case), but allowing that to be overridden with a flag.
Seems like it should always be a long to me.
